items.title: Mirror moment: feeling trapped late-career
items.text:
Sketched storyboard style, pencil lines, minimal shading.
Ada speaks to the camera beside a mirror, her reflection visible.
In a small room, she gestures as if warning about feeling trapped by others’ expectations, expression serious.

items.title: Curiosity Loop: quick structured outreach
items.text:
Sketched storyboard style, pencil lines, minimal shading.
Ada at her desk drafting and sending an email with a structured prompt, a list of 2–3 topics visible on her screen.
As she hits send, replies begin appearing in her inbox, with a note about anonymized feedback.

items.title: How to structure it: good question + right people
items.text:
Sketched storyboard style, pencil lines, minimal shading.
Ada stands at a whiteboard in a simple office, pointing as two on-screen examples show a vague question crossed out and a specific unbiased question highlighted.
Beside it, she writes two advisor criteria: “expertise” and “knows you,” and a small note: “keep the ask lightweight,” looking focused.

items.title: Personal example: estate planning age debate
items.text:
Sketched storyboard style, pencil lines, minimal shading.
Ada and her partner sit at a kitchen table with notes, casually asking a small group of family/friends about inheritance age (18 vs 25).
The group’s responses cluster away from 18, and one person mentions executive function peaking around 30; the parents look thoughtful.

items.title: Values exercise: building an inner scorecard
items.text:
Sketched storyboard style, pencil lines, minimal shading.
Ada and Lenny sit at a small table with a values word list between them; Lenny reads his chosen values aloud while Ada points to the list.
They apply the values to his dilemma about saying yes or no to projects with a baby on the way, thoughtful mood.

items.title: Early career strategy: explore then exploit
items.text:
Sketched storyboard style, pencil lines, minimal shading.
Ada stands at a whiteboard in a simple office, drawing a timeline: Microsoft → startup → founder → LinkedIn → SurveyMonkey.
She points to two labeled phases, “Explore” then “Exploit,” emphasizing learning goals (growth/subscriptions) over promotions.
